bibl.title: Letter from Jesse T. Lazear to Mabel H. Lazear, October 21, 1921

div1.p: Jesse T. Lazear discusses financial affairs concerning Mabel Lazear and her children.

div1.head: Letter from Jesse T. Lazear to Mabel H. Lazear, October 21, 1921
div1.opener:
JESSE T. LAZEAR
ATTORNEY AT LAW
PITTSBURGH, PA.
ST. NICHOLAS BLDG.
October 21, 1921
Mrs. Mable H. Lazear,
#2907 Dwight Way,
Berkeley, California.
My dear Mable;-
div1.p:
I acknowledge receipt of yours of the 21st., en-
closing letter of the Trust Company, dated August 30, 1921,
which I herewith return as requested.

Under the laws of Pennsylvania, prevailing at the
time of Jesse's death, his surviving children inherited his
real estate absolutely subject to the widow's dower, which is
one-third of the real estate, for life, and in a case like this,
where the property has been sold, the one-third of the net pro-
ceeds of the real estate is held in trust during the life of the
widow, and she is entitled to receive the entire income on this
one-third. At her death, the corpus or principal yielding this
income will pass to her children, free of the dower. This is
simply an old common law of England, and the law of most States
where there is intestacy. Of late years, there has been a ten-
dency to modify this, and give the wife an immediate interest in
his real estate, in lieu of dower.

I called up Mr. Burguin, and he has confirmed my
idea on the subject that the amount held by the Trust Company
is one-third of the net proceeds of the sale of the Frankstown
Avenue property to Ludebuhl. I do not consider it material to
ascertain the exact amount being held, but at a guess. I think it
was $8000 or $9000, and my recollection is that it is about one-
third of the net proceeds of the sale, after the payment of Jesse's
obligations, which, as I recall it, were a judgment note of $6000.
given to father in settlement of his account, and also a mortgage
of $6000, which was borrowed on the property at the time the build-
ing was erected thereon. You will find among Jesse's papers, a
complete accounting in the matter, and I recall, at the time of his
death or sale, you asked for an explanation of his indebtedness,
which were evidenced by the mortgage and the judgment.

You will therefore understand that during your life,
you are entitled to the income on this sum so held, and after your
death, the children will receive the principal, and of course the
Trust Company cannot advance you any of the principal, unless the
Mrs. Mable H. Lazear (2).
children assign a portion of this sum to you, and direct it to be
paid immediately. I think this could be worked out with the ap-
proval of the court.

I am glad to hear from you, and with regard to the
children. I attended an audit in court on Wednesday by which Mar-
garet received. I think, about $12,000., being her share with some
accumulations on the proceeds of the sale above mentioned. I should
answer your interrogatory that the same situation applies to the
Denniston Avenue property, one-third of the net rents of which you
are entitled to receive, and if the property were sold, you would
receive one-third of the interest realized from the fund.

My own idea is that this property should be sold if
it can be sold advantageously, for the reason that the building
must be very old and is only frame. I would suggest that you have
the children write, expressing their wish to have the property dis-
posed of, if it can be done advantageously. It is however, well
located, and I don't think will depreciate in price very much.

My son John is working diligently with the Duquesne
Steel Works, and Jane is living with her husband at Norfolk, Navy
Yard. They have two very attractive children - a little girl about
five, and a boy about two and one-half.

I look back with great pleasure on your hospitality, and
your artistic surroundings at Santa Barbara, I am sure I saw more
attractive houses there than in any other one location I have ever
visited.
